I could kind of see a future in which Nintendo sues Dell, but I doubt that will happen.
Also, similarities aside, both systems are their own thing. Whereas the Nintendo Switch is a dedicated gaming machine, Dell's concept UFO is more of a portable gaming PC that is (maybe) trying to be like a Nintendo Switch.

snippet.textDisplay:
You say they are open for input?

Well, the corners of the console (the way the l and r bumpers slope downwards) are a bad idea. If you think about how you hold a controller, the meat of the pressing action is on the pad of your fingers towards the centerline of the handheld. If the L and R bumpers slope down, that leaves you unable to press the button in a natural motion if they are hinged bumpers like the Xbox one; you'd either have to curl your fingers and press down on the edges of the bumpers or press down with the knuckle of your finger. Both methods would be uncomfortable.

Unfortunately this is a common design in many 3rd party controllers for Xbox and PlayStation and every one of them I've personally tried or have read reviews on have had the same problem.

Edit: for an analogy think of a gun held in your right hand with a trigger action that instead of going straight backwards had to be pulled slightly to the left. It's an akward and uncomfortable motion
snippet.textOriginal:
You say they are open for input?

Well, the corners of the console (the way the l and r bumpers slope downwards) are a bad idea. If you think about how you hold a controller, the meat of the pressing action is on the pad of your fingers towards the centerline of the handheld. If the L and R bumpers slope down, that leaves you unable to press the button in a natural motion if they are hinged bumpers like the Xbox one; you'd either have to curl your fingers and press down on the edges of the bumpers or press down with the knuckle of your finger. Both methods would be uncomfortable. 

Unfortunately this is a common design in many 3rd party controllers for Xbox and PlayStation and every one of them I've personally tried or have read reviews on have had the same problem.

Edit: for an analogy think of a gun held in your right hand with a trigger action that instead of going straight backwards had to be pulled slightly to the left. It's an akward and uncomfortable motion

snippet.textDisplay:
Truth told. I am super excited for the UFO, but I already know i won't be able to afford it.
Right now the absolute maximum would want to spend on it (as I don't have any spec info) is 700€. That would be my budged for a gaming Laptop (know it's low but I saw some ASUS stuff I could afford with a GTX1050ti and 120Hz screen)

So now lets speak specs.
120Hz screen (with settings to 60Hz for energy saving)
CPU: i3-10110U or slightly lower.
GPU: 1050ti or any other similarly spec-ed GPU.

also 8GB of DDR4 RAM (dual channeled)


Know something new will never be in this Price-Range, with those specs.
To be more realistic.


A Vega 8 or better 11 APU with not so slow RAM (maybe 2600+Mhz) [still 8GB dual channeled] would be fine for 400€. (If possible same screen, but in that Price range I would buy it even with 60Hz).

What I need as a student is a Notebook and I don't have the money for both, but if it has the "700€" specs I could buy it for multipurpose (would probably use it even as new desktop). If it has the 400€ specs I would buy it for gaming and some really old cheap Ultra-book (hopefully below 300€) for my studies. That's my personal situation, though I know a lot a colleagues are in similar ones.

EDIT:
I prepared a pretty detailed income living cost listing to show, that I am a poor student by definition but in the end, I decided against it.
If I get lucky and one of the 2 conditions are cleared I will buy it, if not then I simply will not be able to afford it.
I could live with a 10% decrease in performance (compared to the listed specs) for the suggested price, but could not do it vise versa (same specs but 10% increased price).

snippet.textDisplay:
+1 for having a detachable keyboard accessory on the UFO. With that this becomes my go-to travel machine.

With that plus the dock they've shown, the UFO becomes my HTPC/Steam in-home streaming machine at home, and my mini-laptop/game console on the go.

I'd guess this would be coming in around the $750 to $1000 USD price point, so any way to get more value of it would be ideal. Some ideas:

- Make it a half decent Windows tablet/mini-laptop experience so I can leave my laptop at home if I don't need a huge screen. Basically a Surface Go with some real horsepower.
- Quad-core and the option for 16 gigs of ram (8 gigs base is probably fine) plus upgradable storage for heavier games / applications (would like it to run Lightroom decently for traveling). I'd want Ryzen 4000 personally, but I also like the idea of TB3 for expansion, so it's a bit of a toss up.
- The 1920x1200 resolution at 60hz seems like the sweet spot at this size, just be sure it's a decent IPS panel and give us adaptive sync for bonus points.
- Offer a decent travel docking solution (HDMI/USB/Power in), this is a HUGE drawback on the switch (having to pack that giant dock.)
- Enough battery to last 1 - 1.5 hrs of heavy gaming (100% utilization), 2 - 3 hrs of lighter gaming, 4 - 5 hrs of desktop/web browsing. More is great but don't add too much to the weight. Couch this by offering USB PD in support so the mobile crowd can get one of those giant Anker battery banks and game on off that for 10+ hours.
- Personally I'd like something less "gamery", but maybe that's a Dell version with a different shell down the road.

Those are the main things. Hit all those points and you can take my money.
snippet.textOriginal:

I'd guess this would be coming in around the $750 to $1000 USD price point, so any way to get more value of it would be ideal. Some ideas:

- Make it a half decent Windows tablet/mini-laptop experience so I can leave my laptop at home if I don't need a huge screen. Basically a Surface Go with some real horsepower. 
- Quad-core and the option for 16 gigs of ram (8 gigs base is probably fine) plus upgradable storage for heavier games / applications (would like it to run Lightroom decently for traveling). I'd want Ryzen 4000 personally, but I also like the idea of TB3 for expansion, so it's a bit of a toss up. 
- The 1920x1200 resolution at 60hz seems like the sweet spot at this size, just be sure it's a decent IPS panel and give us adaptive sync for bonus points.
- Offer a decent travel docking solution (HDMI/USB/Power in), this is a HUGE drawback on the switch (having to pack that giant dock.) 
- Enough battery to last 1 - 1.5 hrs of heavy gaming (100% utilization), 2 - 3 hrs of lighter gaming, 4 - 5 hrs of desktop/web browsing. More is great but don't add too much to the weight. Couch this by offering USB PD in support so the mobile crowd can get one of those giant Anker battery banks and game on off that for 10+ hours. 
- Personally I'd like something less "gamery", but maybe that's a Dell version with a different shell down the road. 

Those are the main things. Hit all those points and you can take my money.

snippet.textDisplay:
To the UFO:
Would be nice to see straight sides and, when it comes to accessories, a regular keyboard/trackpad combo, a dock with a ton of IO, almost the amount of IO you get on a full tower. A dock that you can buy to replace the one regular one that has a slot for a GPU. All this, and then it could be the perfect combo/replacement for a laptop, a desktop pc and a portable console, all-in-one.
snippet.textOriginal:
To the UFO:
Would be nice to see straight sides and, when it comes to accessories,  a regular keyboard/trackpad combo, a dock with a ton of IO, almost the amount of IO you get on a full tower. A dock that you can buy to replace the one regular one that has a slot for a GPU. All this, and then it could be the perfect combo/replacement for a laptop, a desktop pc and a portable console, all-in-one.
